H0.text: Water expands when it freezes is the property of water that most likely causes large rocks to break apart.

H1.text: Water forming droplets as it falls is the property that most likely causes large rocks to break apart.

H2.text: Water turning into a gas when it boils is a property of water that most likely causes large rocks to break apart.

H3.text: Water takes the shape of its container, a property of water that most likely causes large rocks to break apart.

A4.text: When water freezes to ice, its volume increases by nine percent. Under specific circumstances, this expansion is able to displace or fracture rock.

A5.text: The traditional explanation for frost weathering was volumetric expansion of freezing water.
